intro: Racinaea pectinata, commonly known as the pectinate racinaea, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the family Araceae, which includes many aquatic and semi-aquatic plants. The plant is characterized by its distinctive pectinate leaves, which have a feathery, ribbon-like structure. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically clustered in an inflorescence called a spadix, surrounded by a modified leaf called a spathe. Racinaea pectinata is often found in wetland habitats and is adapted to thrive in waterlogged soils.
